Topological View}}$We first introduce some embedding and approximation theorems, and then follows the proof. $\textbf{[Preparations]}$ $\textcolor{darkgreen}{\textit{1. Whitney Approximation Theorem}}$Let $M$ be a $\textcolor{brown}{\textit{smooth manifold}}$ and let $F: M \to \mathbb{R}^k$ be a $\textcolor{darkblue}{\textit{continuous}}$ function. Whitney Embedding Theorem}}$$\textcolor{darkgreen}{\textit{3. Corollary}}$If $F,G: M\to N$ are homotopic smooth maps, then they are $\textcolor{brown}{\textit{smoothly homotopic.}}$ If $F$ is homotopic to $G$ relative to some closed subset $A \subset M$, then they are smoothly homotopic relative to $A$. $\textbf{[Proof]}$ By virtue of these properties of homotopy, one can apply Stokeâ€™s Theorem which demands both $M$, the oriented $n-$dimensional manifold with boundary, and $\omega$, the compactly supported $(n-1)-$form on $M$, are smooth. $\textcolor{darkgreen}{\textit{Definition: }}$$\textbf{Exact Differential Forms}$: $\exists f\in C^{\infty}(M)$ such that $\omega = df$.$\textbf{Closed Differential Forms}$: $d\omega = 0$. $\textcolor{darkgreen}{\textit{Local Exactness of Closed covector field}}$$\omega$: a closed covector field on a smooth manifold $M$.
